article_title: Chasers manager sees minimal effect as minor league baseball adjusts to pitch clock
article_text:
:20 — Time between pitches within an inning. The clock starts once the pitcher receives the ball in the mound area and stops when he begins his windup or comes set. A pitcher can reset the clock by stepping off the rubber. A batter or catcher can do so by requesting and being granted a timeout. The clock is not used on the pitch following a foul ball.

2:25 — Amount of time between half-innings. Pitchers must have thrown their final warm-up pitch by the time the clock reaches 35 seconds. The catcher and batter must be ready to go by the time it expires.

og.description: Omaha reliever Scott Alexander had finished his warm-up pitches and was ready to go. With a runner at first, he was working from the stretch. Alexander nodded at a sign from catcher Francisco Pena. But before he came set, Round Rock’s Brett Nicholas stepped out of the batter’s box.

article_metadata.description: Omaha reliever Scott Alexander had finished his warm-up pitches and was ready to go. With a runner at first, he was working from the stretch. Alexander nodded at a sign from catcher Francisco Pena. But before he came set, Round Rock’s Brett Nicholas stepped out of the batter’s box.

article_summary:
Pitchers must have thrown their final warm-up pitch by the time the clock reaches 35 seconds.
The clock is not used on the pitch following a foul ball.
The clock starts once the pitcher receives the ball in the mound area and stops when he begins his windup or comes set.
The catcher and batter must be ready to go by the time it expires.
A batter or catcher can do so by requesting and being granted a timeout.
